title: Voleur HTB
description: An Active Windows machine where you perform Active Directory enumeration with BloodHound and LDAP queries, exploit Kerberoasting to crack service account hashes, abuse NTLM relay attacks, and escalate privileges via AD ACL misconfigurations.

title: Rustykey HTB
description: A hard Windows AD machine where you enumerate domain controllers, abuse ASREPRoast to retrieve KRBTGT hashes, perform DCSync to dump all domain credentials, and leverage NTLM relay to gain elevated access.

title: Dashboarded HTB Business CTF 2025
description: In this cloud‑based ICS challenge you enumerate AWS IAM roles, exploit misconfigured S3 buckets to harvest credentials, perform SSRF via the monitoring dashboard, enumerate CloudTrail to locate sensitive logs, and escalate privileges through EC2 instance metadata abuse.

title: Volnaya Forums HTB Business CTF 2025
description: A white‑box web CTF where you analyze source code, exploit an IDOR to access /flag.txt, chain broken access control with cross‑site scripting to inject a webhook for exfiltration under CORS restrictions, and abuse a bot‑based report system to execute code as admin.

title: Active HTB
description: A Windows AD machine where you gather domain information via BloodHound, perform LDAP query enumeration, crack Kerberoastable SPNs, relay NTLM authentication, and exploit insecure group policies to escalate to DA.

title: Alert HTB
description: A Linux machine centered on log monitoring bypass: you exploit LFI in a web‑app to poison logs, leverage sudo misconfigurations, and execute commands as root via crafted syslog entries.

title: Analytics HTB
description: An easy Linux machine with a Metabase instance vulnerable to pre-auth RCE (CVE-2023-38646), leveraged to gain a Docker container shell; enumerate environment variables for SSH creds, then exploit the GameOverlay vulnerability for root.

title: BoardLight HTB
description: An IoT firmware challenge: extract the device image, reverse‑engineer via binwalk, dump JTAG‑accessible partitions, bypass UART login, and exploit a hardcoded backdoor to gain root on the embedded system.

title: Broker HTB
description: A message‑broker machine hosting Apache ActiveMQ vulnerable to unauthenticated RCE; post‑exploit, abuse a sudo misconfiguration to run nginx as root for complete takeover.

title: Buff HTB
description: A Gym Management System 1.0 challenge with unauthenticated RCE and a second-stage CloudMe buffer‑overflow exploit to bypass NX/ASLR and spawn a root shell.

title: Cap HTB
description: A Linux capture‑server with IDOR-based PCAP retrieval to harvest FTP creds, then abuse file capabilities (cap_setuid) to spawn a root shell via Python.

title: Cicada HTB
description: An easy Active Directory DC with SMB, Kerberos, LDAP services; enumerate shares, extract plaintext creds, password‐spray, and abuse SeBackupPrivilege for full compromise.

title: Codify HTB
description: A Node.js sandbox (vm2) Escape challenge: chain multiple CVEs in vm2 for RCE, extract a hash from SQLite for SSH, then abuse a sudo‐run backup script to escalate to root.

title: CozyHosting HTB
description: A Spring Boot web app with Actuator enabled; steal a session, exploit command injection, extract DB creds from the JAR, crack hashes for SSH, then abuse sudo‑ssh ProxyCommand for root.

title: Devvortex HTB
description: A Joomla CMS challenge: leak DB creds via information disclosure (CVE‑2023‑23752), create a webshell for user, then exploit an apport‑cli pager bug for root.

title: Dog HTB
description: An easy Linux web challenge: enumerate BackDrop CMS, leak the Git repo via directory scan, extract credentials from settings.php, perform a password spray, and escalate via SeBackupPrivilege.

title: Editorial HTB
description: A CMS‑based web machine: you perform blind and error‑based SQL injection to enumerate the database, exploit insecure file uploads to deploy a webshell, and leverage misconfigured plugins to escalate to admin.

title: EscapeTwo HTB
description: A sandbox escape box: you exploit escape sequence parsing in a custom script, bypass the chroot jail via symlink abuse, and execute arbitrary commands on the host.

title: Jerry HTB
description: A Linux box abusing cron‑based symlink vulnerabilities: identify a root cron job, craft a symlink to overwrite /etc/shadow, and escalate to root via passwordless login.

title: LinkVortex HTB
description: A CSRF challenge: craft malicious links to steal auth tokens, predict anti‑CSRF tokens, chain session fixation to hijack admin access, and execute privileged actions.
